publications.citationremarks: Artist:Gogh, Vincent vanArtist Dates:1853-1890Title:Self-Portrait Dedicated to Paul GauguinDate of Work:1888Culture:DutchMedium:Oil on canvasImage Number:4WP42Description:23 1/4 x 19 in (sight)Bequest from the Collection of Maurice Wertheim, Class of 1906, 1951.65Provenance: Van Gogh painted in 1888; gift to Paul Gauguin, 1888; sold for 300 ff., 1896 or 1897; Ambrose Vollard, Paris; Paul Cassirer (dealer), Berlin; Mrs. Hugo von Tschudi, Munich; Neue Staatsgalerie, Munich; sold to Maurice Wertheim of New York at Entartete Kunst sale at Fisher Gallery, Lucerne, as lot no. 45, June 30, 1939.Van Gogh painted thirty-seven self-portraits during his lifetime, in an attempt to create a new, more expressive portraiture that would capture a broader audience for contemporary painting. This canvas was part of an exchange of portraits between van Gogh, Paul Gauguin, and Emile Bernard. In this self-portrait, van Gogh deliberately transformed and exaggerated his own features, as he explained to his brother Theo in a letter. "Someday you will also see my self-portrait, which I am sending to Gauguin, because he will keep it, I hope... I have made the eyes SLIGHTLY slanting like the Japanese." To Gauguin himself, van Gogh wrote that he wanted to convey the impression of a simple Buddhist monk. The acquisition of this painting by Maurice Wertheim was fraught with controversy. In the collection of the Neue Staatsgalerie, Munich since 1919, it was denounced by the Nazis along with other examples of modern art as ‘degenerate’ and sold at auction in 1939 in Switzerland.  Many collectors refused to purchase works from this sale,  not wishing to participate in any transaction with the Nazis. Wertheim seems to have felt that to support what the Nazis detested was justifiable, yet he did not take the opportunity to acquire any of the other works included in the sale which fit into his area of collecting.  —Sarah Kianovsky
